results.title: Bitter welcome
results.creator_credit: Mental Health Film Board, Affiliated Film Producers and Irving Jacoby
results.brief_description: The story of the difficulties encountered by a man recently discharged from a mental hospital; produced to promote understanding of this problem by the general public. Schuster is accepted by his boss as perfectly competent to do the job, but has some difficulty in overcoming the distrust and ignorance of his workmates, which hurt him considerably. His relationship with his wife is damaged by his suspicious attitude to her motives for remaining loyal to him, but he eventually realises the strength of their mutual love and accepts the fact that although not everyone will be on his side, there are some people on whom he can depend.

results.title: Bitter sweet
results.creator_credit: British and Dominions Films, United Artists Corporation and Herbert Wilcox
results.brief_description: Based on Noel Coward’s operetta, this is the first version of “Bitter sweet” (later Hollywood version in 1940 starring Nelson Eddy/Jeanette MacDonald) featuring Anna Neagle, Fernand Graavey and Esme Percy. It tells the romantic tale of a now older Sarah reminiscing about her younger days and her first love Carl, a musician. Charming and melodic, this bitter sweet love story is beautifully filmed by prolific British director and producer, Herbert Wilcox (Nell Gwyn, No No Nanette, The Lady with a Lamp to name a few) assisted by the wonderful dialogue, lyrics and music of Noel Coward. NB: Sound quality is muffled.

results.title: Bitter sweet
results.creator_credit: Victor Saville, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and W S. Van Dyke
results.brief_description: On the eve of her wedding to a priggish Londoner, a Victorian girl and her dashing music teacher elope to Vienna, where he hopes to sell his music. Cast includes Jeanette MacDonald, Nelson Eddy, George Sanders. Original play, music and lyrics by Noel Coward.

results.title: Bitter Surrender
results.brief_description: A documentary about an overlooked aspect of adoption, the experience of mothers who have surrendered or given up their children. Through the personal accounts of five women, it explores and exposes what the legally enforced secrecy surrounding adoption hides, that the majority of women who relinquish their children face seemingly unresolvable shame and grief.

results.title: Bitter Rice
results.creator_credit: Cecil Holmes, Graham Chase and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This is a documentary examining the political struggle in the Philippines. It focuses on the life and exploits of Bernabe Buscayno, alias Kommanda Dante, legendary figure, founder of the New People’s Army, and long time defender of the people. This gripping film looks at Dante’s recent efforts to bring about political and economic change by establishing the People’s Livelihood Foundation - an open co-operative for rice farmers in Capas, which represents the people’s struggle to earn from their land … so far the struggle has been peaceful.

results.title: Bitter paradise: The Sellout of East Timor
results.brief_description: Prior to Indonesian invasion and subsequent occupation, Portugese East Timor was a country far removed from external influences. Anthropologists from the west visted the country as an example of a preserved culture. Canadian tourist and photographer, Elaine Briere, visited in 1974; her photos remain as some of the only documents that attest to the peaceful existence of the country prior to invasion. Briere presents a harsh case against Western society, in particular Canada, and their complicity in allowing the military elite of the Suharto government to invade East Timor. A move that was motivated by a desire to control raw material and exploit new markets. Briere’s photographs and the testimonies provided by East Timorese who survived to tell of the atrocities that occurred are compiled as a photo documentary of the solidarity movement. More than anything, this documentary is a moving tribute to a country with a determination to maintain their independence and culture from assimilation, as well as promoting awareness of the East Timor occupation. Warning: This documentary contains scenes which may offend some viewers.

results.title: Bitter moon = Lunes de fiel
results.creator_credit: Les Films Alain Sarde, Canal+, R P Productions, Timothy Burrill Productions and Roman Polanski
results.brief_description: This dark-humored comedy drama explores perverse sexual obsession in a marriage based on mutual hatred. While on a luxury cruise to Istanbul a repressed English couple, Nigel and Fiona, (played by Hugh Grant and Kristin Scott-Thomas) meet a crippled American writer and his beautiful French wife. As the American entertains Nigel with elaborate accounts of the sexual power games he and his wife play (related in lengthy flashbacks), the English couple’s curiosity is aroused. Gradually they become drawn into their twisted and ultimately destructive relationship as unwitting observers and participants in a tragedy with the most extraordinary outcome. Cast also includes Peter Coyote and Emmanuelle Seigner.

results.title: Bitter coffee = Secangkir kopi pahit
results.creator_credit: Sanggar Film, Bambang Widitomo, Njoohan Siang and Teguh Karya
results.brief_description: In one of his finest works, Teguh Karya takes an inside look at the lives of working-class ethnic Bataks in Indonesia through the film’s main character, Togar. The film opens with Togar being arrested after his wife has drowned, with the remainder of the film being told in flashbacks. The story unfolds with Togar having gone to Jakarta to pursue his ambition of being a journalist and meeting an older divorced woman at a local foodstall. He is subsequently forced to marry her when it turns out she is pregnant, only to find out later the child might not be his. He forgives his wife however and takes her, together with her children, back to his village in Jogjakarta to meet his mother, the setting of the unfortunate drowning accident. The film provides an interesting window into the lives of many such Indonesians like Togar as well as the city of Jakarta and its influence on those that live there. Cast includes Rina Hassim, Ray Sahetapy, Dewi Yull and Alex Komang. In Indonesian with English subtitles.

results.title: Bits and pieces
results.creator_credit: Leisl Hillhouse, Emerald Films and Simon Klaebe
results.brief_description: A seemingly innocent “neat freak” (Jeremy Callaghan) patiently, yet swiftly cleans his house, under the watchful eye of a dog who may or may not be the cause of the proliferation of waste. As the milkman arrives to replenish the bottles, the plot takes an unexpected twist.

results.title: Bits and bytes. Parts 1-12
results.creator_credit: Time-Life Video, TV Ontario, Denise Boiteau, David Stansfield and Stuart Beecroft
results.brief_description: Part 1. ‘Getting started’. Part 2. “Ready made programs’. Part 3. ‘How programs work’. Part 4. ‘Storing information’. Part 5. ‘Communication between computers’. Part 6.’Computer languages’. Part 7. ‘Computer assisted instruction’. Part 8. ‘Learning objectives’. Part 9. ‘Computer Graphics’. Part 10 ‘Computer music’. Part 11. ‘Computers at work’. Part 12 ‘What next’. Based on the Apple II series computer, and IBM, there are sound basic explanations about basic computer functions and programs.
